morningdefense@politico.com SPENDING DEAL STILL ELUSIVE, AS CONGRESS PREPS SHORT-TERM SPENDING BILL:  . . . .the omnibus negotiations remain unresolved.  . . . [there's a]  stare-down between new House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) and Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.): "The past few years on Capitol Hill, deadline-driven fiscal battles have been fueled by sharp ideological differences. Clashes over Obamacare, Planned Parenthood funding and immigration policy have all led to partisan showdowns and one government shutdown. This time, however, the end-of-year spending fight is turning out to be mostly a test of patience, as well an early challenge for how Ryan intends to run the House." "House Democrats, who made a new offer to Republicans on Wednesday to break the stalemate over the omnibus, know Ryan will be able to deliver only a sliver of the Republican Conference for any spending bill, so he'll need a sizable number of Democratic votes to pass anything. So Democrats believe they should hold firm in their demands. The negotiations are intertwined with talks over a separate, sprawling year-end tax extenders measure." " HOW THEY'LL KEEP THE LIGHTS ON: "With both sides confident that time is on their side, there is no pressure for a quick agreement; for Ryan and Pelosi, a good deal is more important than a quick deal. The House on Friday will vote on a short-term funding measure to keep the government open until Dec. 16, and additional continuing resolutions are possible."
Now it sounds like President Obama will sign a short CR: http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/dec/9/house-leaders-introduce-short-term-bill-keep-gover/ so reducing 40%.

The fact of an onrushing deadline is interesting but not compelling. I have worked in a lot of legislatures in the US and elsewhere, although not the US Congress. In practically all of them, budget negotiations go on until practically the last available minutes--sometimes longer, where the artifice of officially stopping the clock before midnight is legal.  (Many years ago in the Illinois House, there was a member who actually clambered up a convenient column and physically pushed the clock hands back; a technically unnecessary maneuver, but it gave him great pleasure and considerable exercise.)

morningdefense@politico.com "The government runs out of funding in eight days, and appropriators appear to still have some work to do to fashion an omnibus spending bill, as Democrats rejected the first version offered by Republicans, reports POLITICO's Jake Sherman and John Bresnahan: "With just a little more than a week to go before the government runs out of money, Capitol Hill has entered the deal-swap phase, as Democrats and Republicans trade proposals to fund the federal government for the next year. "House Democrats, who opposed many of the so-called policy riders in the Republican's first funding proposal, say they are preparing to deliver their counteroffer to the GOP ... The back-and-forth is certainly late in the game, but it does represent an important development: the two sides are actively swapping proposals and that could help them whittle down their differences." - NO NEED TO PANIC, BUT PASSAGE COULD BE DELAYED: "The apparent stalemate - which started Tuesday - raises the odds that the House will need to pass a short-term stopgap bill to fund the government for anywhere from a few days to a week while the two parties iron out their differences. Ryan (R-Wis.) and House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) had hoped to unveil a spending package next Monday in advance of a late-week vote to avert a government shutdown. That timeline is still possible, but negotiations would need to speed up significantly. Top aides in both parties do not expect a government shutdown this month."
~~~~~~~

politicoplaybook@politico.com "Republicans try to kill Paris climate pact by holding the funding hostage," by Politico's Darren Goode and Andrew Restuccia: "On Dec. 11, Obama administration diplomats will be in Paris working to cinch a global climate deal that will hinge on whether they can back up a pledge to provide billions of dollars to help poor countries deal with climate change. That same day, Republicans back in Washington will be trying to hold that money hostage with a government shutdown hanging in the balance. 'We want to make sure that any of these countries that think they're going to have a check to cash ... that they shouldn't cash the check just yet,' Sen. John Barrasso (R-Wyo.) said of Republicans' strategy. "Congress must pass a new spending bill by Dec. 11, when a stopgap measure expires. The simultaneous deadlines ... give Republicans a tool to derail a legacy-defining pact for the president ... Barrasso and Sen. James Inhofe (R-Okla.), the chairman of the Environment and Public Works Committee, who also doubts mainstream climate science, sent Obama a letter Friday warning that 'Congress will not be forthcoming' with climate aid unless a Paris deal is submitted to the Senate for ratification."
~~~~~~~

Dateline 10-28-15 Republican leaders are pushing a House floor vote on their budget package on Wednesday, after making last minute changes to the bill to quell discontent over its cost. If the deal makes it to the floor, it is likely to pass, if only because House GOP leaders need just 40 to 50 Republicans to back it. Democrats and GOP moderates have embraced the agreement, which raises the so-called “sequester” budget caps for two years for defense and domestic spending and increases the country’s borrowing limit until March 2017. Senate leaders are also behind the deal. [Sign up for The Daily 202, The Washington Post’s new political tipsheet] House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif) said Wednesday morning that there would be enough votes to pass the deal later in the day. “It’s a good package,” she said. “We’ll have enough votes.” Some Republicans raised concerns late Tuesday that the bill only includes about $75.7 billion in spending cuts and increased revenue, according to the Congressional Budget Office, which is about $4 billion short of the $80 billion in spending increases. But the budget office confirmed Wednesday that a series of late-night changes to the bill made by leaders ensured that all of the spending increases would be offset. The House is expected to vote Wednesday evening on the deal. If it passes, the Senate could begin work as early as Thursday. Congressional leaders used a tax bill that already passed the House as the vehicle for the agreement in order to speed up the procedural process in the Senate. Presidential candidate Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) said Tuesday that he plans to filibuster the bill, but his chances of slowing down passage are limited. The agreement will have to clear one procedural hurdle with at least 60 votes before it can be approved by a simple majority. The final vote could come as early as Monday. https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2015/10/28/house-republican-leaders-push-for-floor-vote-on-budget-despite-conservative-objections/

"Yet nine of last year’s 28 Republican supporters have left Congress and at least three of their Republican successors — Representatives Dave Brat of Virginia, Steve Knight of California and Mark Walker, Republican of North Carolina — are almost certain to be opposed. "Also, 14 Democrats who voted to increase the debt limit are gone, replaced by Republicans, some of whom are likely to vote no. “You have got to be able to say that something is big enough that you would shut down the government,” Mr. Knight told a California radio station on Friday. Mr. Knight, who replaced Howard McKeon, a Republican supporter of the last debt-ceiling increase, added, “We have got to stop digging at some point and make people understand that we have got to have a balanced budget that works on knocking down the deficit, or our children are going to have a much, much different country.” "Representative Kevin McCarthy of California, the majority leader, told reporters on Tuesday that he did not think a debt-ceiling increase could pass the House without significant spending cuts attached, a deal President Obama has repeatedly said he will not negotiate. "Chris Krueger of Guggenheim Securities, the Washington analyst who this week warned clients of the hazards ahead, predicted that the borrowing limit would be lifted. “But we are basing that on nothing more than blind faith,” he said, adding, “To the best of our knowledge, the Treasury has never been in such a difficult position going into a debt ceiling showdown with Congress.”
. . . 
"Leaders of the Republican-controlled Congress had long expected a December deadline. Now, facing the need for expedited action, they are beset by chaos. Hard-line conservatives pressed Speaker John A. Boehner to announce his resignation, leaving the party openly at war over a successor. Those same conservatives, the roughly 40 members of the House Freedom Caucus, are emboldened to force the kind of debt-limit confrontation with Mr. Obama that they say Mr. Boehner shied away from. “It’s a three-ring circus over there,” said Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Senate’s No. 3 Democrat, “which you might laugh at, except the consequences are so serious.” "A separate coalition of conservatives that includes most House Republicans, the Republican Study Committee, on Tuesday outlined conditions it would demand that Mr. Obama meet. These include $3.8 trillion in savings, mainly from entitlements like Medicare and Medicaid, and a balanced-budget constitutional amendment, which could not win congressional approval without the leverage of a debt crisis. "Just like that, the fall’s high-stakes budget talks are off to a rough start. "But senators in both parties expressed some concern that the early elbow throwing could stymie a broad budget agreement between the two Senate leaders. "The relationship is “about where it’s been for a long time: It has its moments of productivity, and a long history of differences over some fundamental issues and how to run the Senate,” said Senate Minority Whip Dick Durbin, Reid’s No. 2.
. . . 
"Sources close to the leaders privately said their relationship has always been tense and seems to be getting worse . . . "Neither is known for being chummy, and beyond brief private talks on the floor preceding their often bitterly partisan speeches there’s little day to day contact between the two . . . 
. . . 
"Their working relationship on the floor has been in a deep freeze for years.
. . .
“They give the same speech every morning. Always about how bad the other is,” lamented one Republican senator. Asked how much of that is for show, the senator replied: “All of it … they’ll both cut a deal.” "Both leaders consider themselves pragmatists at heart. . . .
. . .
"McConnell, a dispassionate tactician who’s been able to strike key fiscal deals with Vice President Joe Biden, sees the White House as more of an honest broker than Reid in a major negotiation like a two-year budget blueprint. "To McConnell loyalists, working with Reid just invites drama. They view him as someone who fights his battles in the press and with over-the-top insults, a turnoff for the taciturn and calculating GOP leader. “I’m sure that with fewer people you have in the room, the more serious the negotiations and discussion, and in a quicker way,” said South Dakota Sen. John Thune, the third-ranking Senate Republican.
. . .
"Already, some red lines are being drawn: McConnell will demand that any bump-ups to existing spending caps be offset with savings elsewhere. He won’t accept tax hikes to pay for them, although other revenue-raisers such as fee increases could be an option.
. . . 
“The question is what he’s promised these 40 off-the-deep end guys.  . . . It’s hard to see how things get better with Boehner leaving.” "Democrats, for their part, are demanding domestic spending increases, which some hawkish Republicans are willing to accept in exchange for more money for the Pentagon that was slashed under a 2011 deficit-reduction deal. But many fiscal conservatives in the Capitol are happy with the lower budget caps for both domestic and defense – spending limits from the Budget Control Act that McConnell has regularly touted with pride as one of his big achievements. "Still, many senators are already sounding this refrain: No more stopgap continuing resolutions. . . . McCain (R-Ariz.) said he has “voted for my last CR,” angrily adding: “I will not stand by and watch our military be destroyed.” Durbin said he wouldn’t support another continuing resolution either: That would be a “disaster.” "McConnell’s allies say Reid is largely to blame for the frosty relationship, noting that the minority leader has blockaded key measures such as annual appropriations bills. Republicans were guilty of similar tactics in the minority. http://www.orlandosentinel.com/opinion/os-ed-government-shutdown-front-center-20150928-story.html Sept 29.  "Since the first full implementation of the modern budget process in 1976, there have been 18 "funding gaps," where funds were not appropriated for at least one day. However, before 1980, the government did not shut down but continued normal operations through six funding gaps. Between 1981 and 1994, all nine funding gaps occurred over a weekend, and government operations were only minimally affected.There have only been three "true" shutdowns. The first two happened in the winter of 1995-1996, when President Clinton and the Republican Congress were unable to agree on spending levels and shut down the government twice for a total of 26 days. The third was in 2013 when the House and Senate standoff on funding resulted in a 16-day shutdown.

COMMENT:  Initially, upon Boehner's announcement of his intention to retire Oct 30th, I read many commentaries suggesting that his successor might enjoy a "honeymoon", a period of Republican party unity.  I'm not reading that anymore.  The tone of the commentaries has grown very dark, suggesting that government dysfunction will be even worse after Boehner leaves.  The silver lining in Boehner's announced retirement is now being described as a determination to pass as much legislation as possible while he is still in the House.  So, much depends on what happens in the next couple of hours, days & weeks.  Will Congress just kick the can down the road to Dec 11th with a CR in the next 2 days?  or will it bite the bullet and pass a full appropriations bill?
boehner took one for the team.  the inmates are on the verge of taking over the asylum.
I am lowering my previous 13% possibility to 0%. There is too much on the line for everyone involved.

Everybody will hate this, but enough Ds will vote with the House Rs to pass a clean continuing resolution, no matter what the knuckle-draggers do. The Senate will concur readily enough, and the Pres will sign it.  House R leadership will allow the crazies to introduce something separate that does what they want, but it won't pass the Senate no matter what the House does, and the Pres won't sign it no matter what the Senate does. The Prince of Orange, being the world's lamest duck, will have virtually no role in this; one almost feels sorry for him.

Boehner has pledged it won't happen on his end and the Senate seems committed to avoid one.  http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2015/09/28/444298984/bill-to-avert-government-shutdown-survives-test-vote-in-the-senate But I wouldn't be shocked if it happened in December.  http://www.vox.com/2015/9/29/9411573/government-shutdown-december What will be different a couple months from now?  It's not certain who the new leadership will be in the House.  It's not certain whether they'd be able/willing to push through a bill over the concerns of a large portion of their party.  Maybe they'll vent their Planned Parenthood concerns through hearings before then, or, the hearings could just keep the issue on the front burner, locking a significant portion of the party into supporting a shutdown unless PP is "de-funded." Then again, threats of shutdown are common and actual shutdowns are rare.  They may be especially eager to avoid an Xmas time shutdown.  People may have had their fill of shutdown by now.  The leadership may want to assert itself in its early tenure (they'd probably much prefer to avoid it somehow before it comes to that though).

With the incumbent GOP wanting to win the Presidency the general mood will be caution. The party in power in congress is always blamed for the shutdown, not the President or opposition. While the new leadership of GOP will want to raise the Planned Parenthood issue, the proximity of the next election will keep the more radical members in check while they seek to elect a President who can defund PP, and not suffer an inevitable veto they cannot overturn
